BC-NY-CRIME-NYT 
17TH MAN ARRESTED IN CENTRAL PARK SEX ATTACKS

 By C.J. CHIVERS   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   NEW YORK _ The police on Sunday arrested the 17th man suspected
of participating in attacks against women in Central Park after the
National Puerto Rican Day Parade June 11.

   The suspect, Lonnie Hopson, was arrested at his home in Queens
about 1 a.m. Sunday. He was charged with one count of first-degree
sexual abuse, a felony, and one count of first-degree riot. He's
being held pending arraignment.

   Detective George Nagy, a police spokesman, said Hopson was
recorded on amateur videotape among the frenzied crush of men who
abused dozens of women in the southeastern corner of the park on
June 11. He was arrested without incident, the police said.

   Like almost all of those arrested so far, police said, Hopson,
18, does not have a criminal record.

   The police said detectives were led to Hopson by an anonymous
caller who saw his picture published in newspapers and broadcast on
television. The figure in the picture was distinctive. In it, the
suspect wears a football jersey bearing the number 20 and a thick
gold chain and has his hair braided in wide cornrows.

   The authorities would not say what role they believed Hopson
played in the attacks, saying that more details would emerge when
he was arraigned.

   The police have released photographs of 20 other men wanted for
their roles in the attack.

   In successive news conferences Sunday, members of 100 Blacks in
Law Enforcement Who Care, the Rev. Al Sharpton and the National
Organization for Women appeared near the intersection of Central
Park South and the Avenue of the Americas, where the attacks
occurred.

   Sharpton arrived with two women, Ashanna Cover and Josina
Lawrence, who have filed lawsuits against the city. They stood by
the street lamp where the two women say they were attacked.

   ``These women have returned to the scene of the crime,''
Sharpton said. ``Today is Father's Day. We will hope that all
fathers take a stand against this reckless, misogynist behavior and
do what is necessary to restore a sense of security and respect to
our daughters in the city.''

   Sharpton also said he would lead all-male rallies starting next
Saturday, beginning with a rally in Harlem and then moving on from
borough to borough. ``We need to really deal with the fact that
some young men feel it is appropriate and even fun to do what
happened in the park last weekend,'' he said.

   Two hours later, roughly 200 demonstrators arrived at the
intersection and began a march to the Central Park precinct of the
New York Police to protest the department's handling of the
attacks.
